title: The Glossy Years by Nicholas Coleridge, review: minor royals, major tycoons — and me
text:
Considering he is what passes these days for a distinguished man, being Chairman of the Victoria and Albert Museum, Chairman of the British Fashion Council, on the Council of the Royal College of Art, an Ambassador for the Landmark Trust and, for decades, editorial director, later president, of Condé Nast, where he oversaw 140 titles in 27 markets, employing 4,000 staff, Nicholas Coleridge, who says he resembles “an Arab terrorist with staring deep-set eye-sockets,” nevertheless wishes to pass himself off, in these sprightly memoirs, as an ignoramus and a dullard, “firmly categorised as thick”.

At prep school, perhaps because the teaching staff were “incompetents, bullies, recovering prisoners...
